clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Salpingectomy During Laparoscopic Hysterectomy on Ovarian Function
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Salpingectomy During Laparoscopic Hysterectomy on Ovarian Function

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of performing a randomized clinical trial evaluating the effect of salpingectomy (removal of the fallopian tubes) during laparoscopic hysterectomy on ovarian function. The hypothesis is that removal of the tubes can prevent diseases of the fallopian tubes such as infection, hydrosalpinx (fluid-filled tubes)and additional invasive procedures such as further imaging work-ups and further surgery related to the tubes.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in ovarian function as measured by Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH)
primary_outcome.time_frame: AMH blood samples collected prior to surgery at day 1 (the day of the surgery) and at 1 and 3 months after day 1.

secondary_outcome.description: The following routinely collected information will be included in the data analysis: age, body mass index, and surgery indication.
The following surgical outcomes will be collected postoperatively: total operating time, estimated blood loss, surgical complications, and surgical pathology.

arm_group.description: Participants in this group will have their fallopian tubes removed.
Participants in this group will not have their fallopian tubes removed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women ages 18-45 scheduled for laparoscopic hysterectomy with planned preservation of both ovaries.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Carrier for the gene that codes for breast cancer type 1 susceptibility protein (BRCA1) or the gene that codes for breast cancer type 2 susceptibility protein (BRCA 2).
- Personal history of gynecologic cancer
- Pregnancy
- Non-English speaking
- Unable to provide informed consent
